subject: Re: [junit] Programmer Tests and the Database
msgSnippet: ... *Shrug*. So basically, you re saying you don t want to test that the Java code you write is using the SQL correctly, and interpreting the results
messageBody:
On Mon, 10 Feb 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> If I change the SQL statements, then I test the new statements as
> needed. That's why I put them in one place, to make them easier to test
> all at once and in isolation from the rest of the system.

*Shrug*. So basically, you're saying you don't want to test that the
Java code you write is using the SQL correctly, and interpreting the
results correctly. That's your call, I guess, but you're going to be the
one that loses when someone changes an SQL statement to return one less
parameter, because you'll never know that the class using that statement
now can't read the ResultSet.

cjs
